Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Situation2: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Story: I was sitting in the lifeguard chair, my phone buzzing in my pocket. It was a message from my colleague, just a quick update about the project timeline. She’d written, “No rush, just FYI,” but I knew our team valued quick responses, even for non-urgent things. I started typing a reply, wanting to show I was attentive and reliable. Out of the corner of my eye, I noticed a small splash in the deep end—where kids weren’t supposed to be. A child was flailing, clearly out of their depth. My heart pounded. I knew the rules: as a lifeguard, my focus had to be on the pool, enforcing safety, ready to act in an instant. But the pressure to be a good colleague tugged at me, the expectation to always be reachable, always responsive. My thumb hovered over the send button, my eyes darting between the screen and the struggling child. I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my attention in that critical moment.
